Last Epoch is the ARPG that feels like it was made by someone who loves Diablo II, hates PoE, yet secretly plays both at 3 a.m. It gives you a bunch of deep systems but with this friendly vibe of ‚Äúdon‚Äôt worry, you don‚Äôt need a spreadsheet to play‚Äù ‚Äî the kind of reassuring promise whispered by a game that clearly knows you‚Äôve spent years tormenting yourself with passive trees, breakpoints, loot filters, and questionable build decisions at ungodly hours. It wraps its complexity in a warm, nostalgic glow, like an old-school ARPG trying to act casual while absolutely knowing it‚Äôs about to consume your entire weekend.

[b]Pro's:[/b]
[LIST][*] Trade or Solo Factions - there's the Merchant's Guild that provides an auction house for players to trade items with others or the Circle of Fortune that doesn't allow for trade but boosts items drops substantially to compensate, allowing players to play how they want
[*] Class Identity - every mastery class does play differently, once you've unlocked their full set of skills
[*] Skill System - each skill has a robust skill tree of ~30 nodes that generically or substantially change it
[*] Crafting - generally easy to understand but has some advanced options available that allow you to create very powerful items somewhat easily
[*] Endgame - while not varied to the levels of PoE, what is available in the Monolith of Fate is fun to do for many hours (more for some and less for others) with factions to progress that improve items drops and alter the content you engage with
[*] Progression - character power has noticeable growth during the first ~75 levels, but slows as you progress closer to level 100, making building many characters a fun overall experience
[*] Loot Filter - very easy to understand and robust loot filter that is built into the game
[*] WASD, Controller, and Kb&M Support - I play with controller and it's been fairly good and continues to get better
[*] Full Offline Mode - if you don't want to connect to the internet then there's a launch option that provides this, but just know that offline saves are stored on your computer and can't be used online while online saves are stored on EHG servers and can't be used offline
[*] Easy to Learn - built in Game Guide that explains nearly every aspect of the game
[*] QoL Features - items drop identified, 200 unlockable stash tabs, materials have their own storage and drop in bunches that are picked up with a single click, etc.[/LIST]

[b]Mid:[/b]
[LIST][*] The Campaign - it's very on rails with little exploration throughout, lacking significant challenges until the endgame
[*] Animations - they're okay, and they've said they're working on improving them so hopefully they get better
[*] Sound - can vary from good to bad, depending on the skill, area, etc. 
[*] Combat Feel - definitely not to the standards of Diablo or PoE2, but passable for most
[*] Arena & Dungeons - these endgame activites are not fleshed out or varied enough to entertain one for very long
[*] Itemization - if the endgame didn't generally devolve into Legendary items in every slot I'd list itemization in the pro's as there's technically a lot of options at your disposal, just none that are as good as Legendaries in most situations[/LIST]

[b]Con's:[/b]
[LIST][*] Incomplete Story - 10 of 12 story chapters are currently in-game
[*] Incomplete Skills - not all base/mastery classes have their full set of skills (Rogue, Bladedancer, Paladin, and Shaman), though this list does typically shrink with each season
[*] Missing 3D Item Art - some equippable items, generally Unique rarity body armours, helmets, boots and gloves, don't have 3D art to match their 2D art, which impacts the power fantasy of equipping cool looking items only to find they don't match
[*] Paradox Classes - future paid DLC, the first likely arriving in Q4 2026, that was recently announced...so not all future content will be free[/LIST]

‚≠ê Total Score: 73/100 ‚Üí 7.3 / 10 (Modest Recommendation)
„Éª It's worth playing for ARPG fans if the change of the parent company doesn't put them off.
„Éª Despite some questionable decisions from the devs, the game can be enjoyed casually.

üïπÔ∏è Core Mechanics & Design: 8/10
+ Build variety is strong and diverse.
+ Progress through skill and ability trees feels satisfying.
+ Skills are highly responsive and lack a "floaty" feeling.
+ Loot filtering system is extensive and highly functional.

- Picking up items and gold can be a pain in the ass. Devs argue pets picking up stuff would be a p2w advantage, but it's a silly argument since they could allow players to acquire a free pet through a quest in the early game and then make in-store pets look visually cooler ... this is a seriously lame decision from the devs considering that pets exist in the game but are functionally useless.
- Itemization system is oddly designed.
- Many Unique items are trash like in D3 and only a select few are worth equipping for their unique effects. Unlike other rarities, you can't upgrade or reroll affixes on Uniques, so you might get a Unique with the effect you want, but the affixes could be garbage.
- Unique items cannot be salvaged for materials.
- Salvaging non-Unique items is unnecessarily expensive.
- Upgrading non-Uniques is a pain in the ass and you'll often run out of forging potential (each attempt to upgrade can potentially decay an item's forging potential down to zero).
- Affix ranges are extremely wide (e.g., 20 to 150), adding further to an already RNG heavy experience.

üîÑ Gameplay Loop, Replayability & Longevity: 9/10
+ The endgame grind is well-designed with additional factions and progression systems.
+ Points earned can be invested to effectively improve the hunt for items and gold.
+ Players can grind in a wide variety of endgame content (echoes/Rifts, arenas, MP dungeons etc.).
+ Developers are actively updating the game with each new Season.

üñºÔ∏è Graphics and art style: 9/10
+ Graphics are excellent, especially for an indie ARPG title.
+ The visual style matches the game.

üéß Sound & Music: 8/10
+ Audio quality is good enough for an indie ARPG.
+ The character loading screen music is memorable.

üìñ Story: 5/10
- The story is incomplete, bland, and often cringy.
- The narrative serves only to add flavor to the gameplay focus.

üåç Setting & Lore: 7/10
+ The concept of different timelines, eras, and regions is implemented decently.
- The depth is barebones, existing primarily to provide basic flavor, similar to the story.

üé≠ Characters & Dialogue: 4/10
- Characters are uninteresting and often cringy.
- Dialogue is lame and uninspired.
- Voice acting is highly inconsistent ("hit or miss," potentially AI-generated).

üíØ Accessibility & Quality of Life (QoL): 10/10
+ The game is easy to pick up for ARPG players compared to games like PoE.
+ Keybind flexibility is good, with the option for WASD vs mouse and keyboard movement.
+ The stash can be expanded considerably, and inventory management is easy.

üì¢ Developer Communication & Future Outlook: 5/10
- Major updates typically take 6+ months since they're limited to the release of a new Season.
- The change in the parent company is a significant negative factor for the game's future outlook.

‚öôÔ∏è Performance, Optimization & Bugs: 8/10
+ No major performance issues encountered on an upper mid-tier PC rig.
+ Some bugs are present, but nothing encountered so far has been game-breaking.

Pros: Combat is great, standard ARPG stuff, kill mass hordes and occasional boss or elite mobs, get loot, get stronger. The big plus i find is in the loot filter system, crafting systems, and the skill trees. 
 - Crafting in this is done where you can add and upgrade affixes on certain items, by using shards that you can get via random drops, or by deconstructing loot you find. 
 - Loot filter lets you see only loot you may want for your build or for deconstructing. No more seeing 50 items on screen and having to filter through to maybe find one that is good for you.
 - skill trees let you specialize in up to 5 of any of your classes learned skills. Each skill has its own tree you can customize, and each class has a level up tree as well to raise character specific passives, and as you sink points into each of the mastery sub-classes you also unlock related class specific skills. 

Overall there is a great deal of character customization available in the game for your playstyle, but i am waiting to see the story fully fleshed out.

"The only form of real money microtransactions Last Epoch will ever have are cosmetic, our currency for such is even named Cosmetic Points (CP) to emphasize this point. I had a fun time playing the game within the time I had with it and within the expectations set by the promises of a non p2w model.
